thread.title: Money lessons from grandparents

author: DAVID & LIBBY KOCH
title: Money lessons from grandparents
text:
GRANDPARENTS may not be savvy on Twitter or know how to use Spotify but a lifetime of experience makes grandparents a fantastic source of old fashioned advice which can be just as relevant today as it was 20 years ago.
And we’re not just saying that because we’re proud grandparents ourselves a few times over now … we’re talking about the advice our grandparents gave us when we were younger.
Today, we’re lucky enough to live in a wealthy country with an abundance of opportunity. But it wasn’t always like that. In fact, it’s likely that your grandparents’ understanding of money was shaped by tougher financial times.
And it’s great to be reminded about these values, because one day (just like us) you’ll be in a position to pass on their wisdom to the next generation.
So on that note, here are five things our grandparents taught us about money that will last forever.
Proud grandparents David and Libby Koch say old fashioned advice can save you a lot of money. Source: Supplied
Always pay with cash
Forget credit cards . If your grandparents didn’t have the money set aside to buy something, it’s simple … they didn’t buy it.
Yes, credit is readily available nowadays, but buying things you can’t afford will inevitably get you into trouble.
So take a leaf out of their book, and pay with cash. Even if it’s just for a month, you’ll learn a lot about where your money is going.
Better still, when you’re using your credit card ... mentally make the link to it being your money. That it is cash.
SETTING A BUDGET: Everything you need to know is on moneysaverHQ
Waste not, want not
Today we’re comfortable using something once and then throwing it away, or replacing something that’s broken rather than fixing it.
But when times are tight, this approach just doesn’t make sense.
You wouldn’t catch your grandparents throwing away food because they forgot to cook it before it spoiled or paying $3 for a bottle of water when they can get it for free out of the tap.
And we bet they knew how to repair things around the house themselves, whether that meant fixing a leaky tap, or stitching up old clothes.
Save the pennies and the pounds will follow
With a lifetime of experience, your grandparents understand better than anyone the importance of taking a long-term approach to building wealth.
They’ll be the first to tell you that over time, a little saved here and there adds up to a significant sum.
This truism is a bit like the title of the classic Paul Kelly song, “From Little Things Big Things Grow”, and it works just as well with dollars and cents as pounds and pennies.
Don’t spray it ... you may want to live a champagne lifestyle but if you can’t afford it you’ll end up in debt. Source: Supplied
Put money away for a rainy day
As with everything in life, there will be good times and bad when it comes to your finances … Just ask your grandparents.
And while you should make every effort to enjoy the good times, it makes sense to have a plan for when things go wrong.
Every now and again, an issue will pop up that you weren’t expecting, like your car breaking down or something more serious such as losing your job.
Having ‘rainy day’ money saved will give you the freedom to ride out the storm and come out better than ever on the other side.
You can’t have champagne taste on a beer budget
Breaking the budget to buy a fancy car, borrowing too much to buy a house in ‘that’ suburb, or any of the other mistakes people make when they’re trying to keep up with the Jones’s are examples of foolish financial behaviour.
You’ll just end up in debt trying to keep up with people who are already there, so instead of trying to buy your way to success, focus on building your career.
Eventually, with a bit of luck and a lot of hard work, you’ll be in a position to buy all of those fancy things.
But by then you’ll probably realise that there’s a lot more to life. Of course, you could have just asked your grandparents.
